title: Development of the HACCP Plan
description: Requirements for HACCP plan development including team formation, training documentation, product descriptions, process flow diagrams, and hazard analysis preparation

requirements.question: Is there a team responsible for the HACCP system at the operation, with an assigned leader for the development, implementation and on-going maintenance of the HACCP system?
Is there documented evidence that the HACCP team members have been trained on HACCP principles?
Does a product description exist for the products produced?
Has the process(es) been flow charted in sufficient detail to completely describe the process or product handling/processing steps?
Is there documented evidence that the flow chart(s) has been verified on-site?

capaInject: Establish corrective actions when HACCP team composition lacks necessary expertise requiring additional training or consultant engagement
Implement procedures for updating HACCP training when team members change or new food safety hazards are identified
Develop action plans when product descriptions are incomplete or inaccurate requiring comprehensive review and revision
Create preventive measures to ensure process flow diagrams are verified on-site whenever process changes occur
Implement verification procedures to confirm hazard analysis preparation includes all biological, chemical, and physical hazards relevant to products
traceabilityInject: Maintain HACCP team documentation including member qualifications, assigned roles, and leadership responsibilities for plan development and maintenance
Keep HACCP training records for all team members documenting course content, completion dates, and certificates from recognized training programs
Retain comprehensive product descriptions including ingredients, processing methods, packaging, storage conditions, and intended use
Document process flow diagrams showing all steps from receiving through distribution with decision points and process parameters identified
Archive flow diagram verification records including on-site walkthrough dates, observations, modifications made, and approval signatures
micro_inject: Inadequate HACCP team training results in failure to identify critical biological hazards including pathogenic E. coli and Salmonella in raw materials
Incomplete product descriptions omit critical information about pH, water activity, or preservatives that control Clostridium botulinum and other pathogens
Unverified process flow diagrams miss cross-contamination opportunities where Listeria monocytogenes can transfer from raw to ready-to-eat products
Poor hazard analysis preparation fails to recognize spore-forming pathogens like Bacillus cereus in temperature abuse scenarios
Insufficient understanding of intended use overlooks vulnerable populations requiring stricter controls for pathogens like Listeria in ready-to-eat foods
